data.title: It's FREE
data.text: The museum is on the smaller side. Some of the things I thought were interesting like the guns, portraits and other CT things. I thought it was okay. Wished it was bigger but the building it was in was beautiful. There is a guard and you walk through a metal detector.

data.title: Portraits of Governors and more
data.text: This is definitely much less than you would expect from the official state history museum of one of the oldest states in the Union. The main attraction is probably the dozens of portraits of Connecticut Governors in the main hall (with the original state charter at the far end). An adjacent room has a lot of guns (gunsmithing is a big part of Hartford's history)  and some Civil War artifacts. The museum is free and worth a stop (if you don't mind passing through a metal detector), but is not worth a special trip.

data.title: Good but could be so much more
data.text:
I first visited this museum many years ago on a field trip.
I decided to revisit it without being surrounded by 12 year olds :)
It is a Saturday in March and I was the only one there.
Peaceful . . . . . ahhhhhhhh.
The building is absolutely beautiful but on Saturdays one must enter through the rear entrance (the basement).  I much rather would have entered through the main entrance.  Much more impressive.
I first toured the portraits of all the governors hanging on the wall.  Very impressive.
I then viewed the displays in Memorial Hall.  
A lot centered around Connecticut's Charter Oak and why we are the Constitution State.
Lots of paraphernalia/medals from WWI and WWII.
Lots of coins from the colonies on.
Great history on the creation of the frisbee (Yale students throwing Frisbie Pies tins).
Lots and lots of Colt firearms history.
So what is missing:
1.  History of all other companies in CT except Colt (there was a little on Pratt & Whitney pre-aircraft engine manufacturing).  What about the typewriter and bicycle companies that were in Hartford?  What about GE?  Why is CT the insurance capital of the world?
2.  What about major weather stories - the hurricane of 1938?  The ice storm in 1975?  The collapse of the civic center roof?
3.  Life stories - what was it like to live in CT in the 1600's?  1700's?  1800's?
4.  What part did the CT River play in CT's history?
5.  Beyond the portraits of the governors, what are they known for?
But remember, the museum is free, so as much as the museum lacked, it was worth the trip.

data.title: Interesting but a little too small...
data.text: I've been surprised to find so little about the Connecticut history... Hopefully, the Connecticut Constitution was there and some pictures about the African American contribution in some fileds of this State. I liked to see a display of many objects of daily life in the 1950 years... I had a quick look on the large guns's area...But, I would have liked to learn more about the French Canadians, Italians, Polishes and Irishes's very important contribution in the development of Connecticut... This little museum has to become bigger and more completed.

data.title: The History of a great State:   Connecticut
data.text: The history of Connecticut is wonderfully shown in all of its glory, bring the past into the present with great art and history as one of the first constitution states!   A must see for the whole family!

data.title: Dirty Harry would have loved the firearms
data.text:
Bitterly cold and snowing on a Saturday morning, a good time to
visit a museum at the State Capitol. Glad I did, very interesting
even though it only covers Connecticut. The colt firearms section
was excellent showing the development of , mainly handguns
from mid 19th century to present day.

data.title: Free museum worth a visit
data.text:
This museum shares a building with the supreme court and Library, so if you are just looking for a museum you might miss it, also on a Saturday enter by the rear of the building.

The museum has many artifacts and some civil war stuff in side rooms to the main room.

I am not a gun nut but found the large collection of Colt weopons very interesting, this area must have been the gun production capital of usa.

the main attraction will be the CT constitution and story of the "charter tree" worth visiting the library and if Saturday take a look into the Supreme court.

It is a bit dated and if anyone from Hartford reads this , some cases need a clean so that you can see the contents.

plan about 1 hour here, parking is also free around the area on a saturday

data.title: Bored
data.text: This is boring. I don't like the guns or anything else. I love history. There is the Connecticut constitution the savior of this museum. X rating 1.5

data.title: A Treasure Trove of CT Artifacts
data.text: Even if you know Connecticut history, there is always something more to learn at this museum.  Compactly displayed, this destination can be seen in less than two hours, in an historic setting.

data.title: Subpar state history museum, but worth a short visit
data.text:
My wife and I visited the Museum of Connecticut History this past week. I give it two circles not because it is "poor", but because it ranks well below other state historical museums I have visited over the years. For instance, the historical museums in Minnesota, Wisconsin and North Carolina are all exciting and extensive, covering multiple floors. This museum is dry, not very innovative and very limited. You can easily see all of it in well under an hour. 
The main hall itself is beautiful, with a very attractive ceiling from the early 1900s. It houses portraits of all of the state governors through John Rowland, four quilts honoring the Underground Railroad, slaves and black history in Ct., and some old-style exhibits on the Charter Oak. In the adjoining rooms there are some exhibits of products once made in Connecticut, and an extensive (but again, very old-style display) dedicated to Colt guns. A Colt aficionado would be very impressed by the collection. 
The museum is free. Unlike pretty much every state museum I have ever seen, there is no shop connected with it there. However, the state Supreme Court is in the same building and is worth a look as well.  If you like history, particularly of Colt firearms or gubernatorial portraits, it's worth a short visit--but it could use an updating.

data.title: 코네티컷의 역사를 한눈에
data.text: 코네티컷이라는 주의 역사를 여러가지 지도와 유물 그림등과 함께 잘 전시해 놓은 박물관입니다. 아주 특별히 인상적이거나 그렇지는 않지만 안에 들어가면 이 주를 더 잘 알게 됩니다.
